A. min to max

change to multi select with covering 50%.

Question 1 (1 pt)

The five-number summary consists of:

A. mean, SD, min, max, median
B. min, Q1, median, Q3, max
C. Q1, Q2, Q3, IQR, range
D. min, mean, median, mode, max

✅ Answer: B

Question 2 (1 pt)

Which statement best describes Q1?

A. 75% of values are below Q1
B. Q1 is the average of the lowest 25%
C. About 25% of values are at or below Q1
D. Q1 is always the smallest value

✅ Answer: C

Question 3 (1 pt)

The IQR is:

A. Q1 − Q3
B. max − min
C. median − mean
D. Q3 − Q1

✅ Answer: D

Question 4 (1 pt)

In a box plot, the box (the rectangle) spans from:

A. min to max
B. Q1 to Q2
C. Q1 to Q3
D. mean to median

✅ Answer: C

Question 5 (1 pt)

In a standard box plot, the line inside the box represents the:

A. mean
B. mode
C. median
D. IQR

✅ Answer: C

Question 6 (1 pt)

The 1.5×IQR rule flags outliers as values:

A. more than 1.5 standard deviations from the mean
B. outside the range [min, max]
C. outside the middle 50%
D. below Q1 − 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR

✅ Answer: D

Question 7 (1 pt)

Which code makes a basic box plot of Index from the data frame Fingers?

A. gf_boxplot(Index ~ Fingers)
B. gf_boxplot(~Fingers, data = Index)
C. gf_boxplot(~Index, data = Fingers)
D. gf_histogram(~Index, data = Fingers)

✅ Answer: C

Question 8 (1 pt)

Which code compares Index distributions by Gender using a box plot?

A. gf_boxplot(~Gender, data = Fingers)
B. gf_boxplot(Gender ~ Index, data = Fingers)
C. gf_boxplot(Index ~ Gender, data = Fingers)
D. gf_histogram(Index ~ Gender, data = Fingers)

✅ Answer: C
